A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. Many others like Voltaire held that without belief in a God who punishes evil, the moral order of society was undermined.

BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. This has caused minor controversy, but is largely recognized as not lending the school any significant advantage, since players receive no athletic and little physical training during their missions.

Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. Prevailing wind patterns that blow offshore minimize the influence of the Atlantic Ocean. The hottest month is July, with a mean temperature of 73.4 °F

As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. The madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, one of the two surviving madaris that predate the founding of the earliest medieval universities and are thus claimed to be the "first universities" by some authors, has acquired official university status as late as 1947. Many insects possess very sensitive and, or specialized organs of perception. Some insects such as bees can perceive ultraviolet wavelengths, or detect polarized light, while the antennae of male moths can detect the pheromones of female moths over distances of many kilometers. The yellow paper wasp (Polistes versicolor) is known for its wagging movements as a form of communication within the colony; it can waggle with a frequency of 10.6±2.1 Hz (n=190). These wagging movements can signal the arrival of new material into the nest and aggression between workers can be used to stimulate others to increase foraging expeditions. There is a pronounced tendency for there to be a trade-off between visual acuity and chemical or tactile acuity, such that most insects with well-developed eyes have reduced or simple antennae, and vice versa. Israel's Supreme Court is at the head of the court system in the State of Israel. It is the highest judicial instance. The Supreme Court sits in Jerusalem. The area of its jurisdiction is the entire State. A ruling of the Supreme Court is binding upon every court, other than the Supreme Court itself. The Israeli supreme court is both an appellate court and the high court of justice. As an appellate court, the Supreme Court considers cases on appeal (both criminal and civil) on judgments and other decisions of the District Courts. It also considers appeals on judicial and quasi-judicial decisions of various kinds, such as matters relating to the legality of Knesset elections and disciplinary rulings of the Bar Association. As the High Court of Justice (Hebrew: Beit Mishpat Gavoha Le'Zedek בית משפט גבוה לצדק; also known by its initials as Bagatz בג"ץ), the Supreme Court rules as a court of first instance, primarily in matters regarding the legality of decisions of State authorities: Government

An adolescent's environment plays a huge role in their identity development. Children who are marginalized can struggle to create a sense of self grounded in positive, nurturing interactions, and the absence of a strong, positive sense-making identity is a powerful force in shaping children's views of themselves (Walsh & Walsh, [2008](#CIT0066)).

A sense of self is a significant asset in a child's life. A sense of self can provide the internal motivation and courage to overcome fears, take risks, and even set and achieve challenging goals. Compared to other team sports, the National Football League preseason is very structured. Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year, plus two Hall of Fame Games that can showcase a team's top players. The preseason is the first time that young players will get a taste of game action in game situations, and they provide valuable experience for coaches' evaluation of players and management of practice time. Also, every team has at least eight former USFL players on its roster.

A good number of USFL players have found NFL success by making the transition from the league to the NFL, but many more have not. Of the USFL's former players, the more notable ones include Jim Kelly, Dan Marino, Randy McMichael, Mike Moroski, Russ Grimm, Doug Williams, and Ken Anderson, among others.

The league's only NFL Hall of Fame inductee was Jerome Bettis in 2013.

As with disqualification, a referee is not required to do this, and only do so if they feel it is necessary.

The palace measures 108 metres (354 ft) by 120 metres (390 ft), is 24 metres (79 ft) high and contains over 77,000 objects.

The palace has undergone two rebuildings, and was built in the Tang dynasty (618-907), on the foundation of a Tang palace from 619.

A Song dynasty palace had been added to the old Tang palace, which was largely destroyed during Taiping Rebellion (1851-1868) before being rebuilt in the early 20th century.

In 2011 the palace complex was added as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, citing its "great architectural and historic significance".

The Tibetan ruler, the 5th Dalai Lama, fled to the Kangxi Emperor for protection, and by 1737 the Qing were forced to recognise the title Dalai Lama as the spiritual leader of Tibet and to appoint the 5th Dalai Lama as their protectorate chief. From 1745 to 1747, Kangxi personally led another campaign of the Dzungar–Qing War and he gained the submission of the eastern Dzungar Khanates which had long resisted the Qing. From the 1970s onward, Stuart Hall's pioneering work, along with that of his colleagues Paul Willis, Dick Hebdige, Tony Jefferson, and later Tim Hall and Joe Moran, generated a vibrant and vital British cultural studies tradition. Hall's research has been much imitated but rarely matched. His work has a strong theoretical foundation, which has informed a broad range of subsequent, often experimental, inquiries into a range of cultural topics. Hall defined cultural studies as a form of cultural analysis in opposition to the structuralism of the 1960s, which had seen culture "reduced to its elements—in the last analysis, discourse." Hall emphasized the role of culture in "intersecting with history, economics, politics, class, gender and everyday life" (Hall 1980: 3).

### The Emergence of Cultural Studies as a Field of Scholarship

What cultural studies has long emphasized is that its domain is constituted by a range of historically defined practices, discourses, institutions, and cultures

Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. Thus, hair color provides an important tool for distinguishing populations and species of organisms; it can also provide additional identifying information for individuals within a population. Hair may differ in color, type, and structure between different organisms, and can reveal important information about an organism's diet, behavior, and genetics. Mammalian hairs develop within a specialized organ called the hair follicle (HF), one of two primary structures involved in hair growth. The other structure is dermal papilla. The HF, which is a cylinder of epithelium and connective tissue supported by an underlying matrix, contains the hair "bulb," a core of cells from which new shafts or "hairs" grow, and the cells that make up the shaft. Most mammals exhibit variation in the color, size, type, and shape of hair, among other physical traits.

Emotions can motivate social interactions and relationships and therefore are directly related with basic physiology, particularly with the stress systems. This is important because emotions are related to our well-being (Mauss et al., 2007). Recent evidence in this area indicates that the quality of relationships is mediated by emotional processes (McCullough and Kilpatrick, 2001). Although, personality characteristics do not cause interpersonal problems, they can predict a person's propensity to engage in interpersonal behavior that might contribute to social stress (Mauss et al., 2007).

The social sciences have long been interested in the relationships among the person, the interaction, and the social context. Thus, it is necessary to investigate the complex relations between physiology and the socioemotional variables that are considered to be related to well-being (e.g., neuroendocrinology, neurobiology, genetics, and psychology).

The implications are multiple as various research traditions are now[when?] heavily utilizing the lens of identity to examine phenomena.[citation needed] One implication of these new modes of inquiry is the use of the term identity as a concept of analysis rather than a self-evident given. In other words, identity is now defined as an object of study rather than a fixed construct of society, a common starting point for much of the critical race and feminist movements. It is also becoming more prevalent in the study of sexuality, in the fields of sociology, history, religious studies, education, literature, political science, anthropology, and linguistics.

Identity is often a part of the social construction of reality in modern societies. Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles give a long critique of the application of FST to human populations in their 2003 paper "Human Genetic Diversity and the Neutral Theory of Speciation" in Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics, Vol. 34.

Long and Kittles note that, while the theory explains the origins of genetic variation within species, it lacks in an explanation in how this new genetic diversity is maintained and whether diversity is generated by allopatric or sympatric speciation. They point out that with a single origin, diversity would be very small, and that human genetic diversity is far greater than would be expected. They also note that human diversification is far more complex than a single speciation event that has been repeated, as the theory requires, but that several speciation events with subsequent migration have taken place. The book was widely translated in Darwin's lifetime, but problems arose with translating concepts and metaphors, and some translations were biased by the translator's own ideas or beliefs. Some translations even went as far as to make the word "evolution" sound as if it was a new scientific theory being introduced. For many people the translation of the word "evolution" made no sense because the word was originally a theological one, not a scientific one. "It [the English] did not use a literal translation of the Latinate term, evolution, but employed it to express a concept of 'progress or development.'"
The first known attempt at an English translation was made by Reverend John William Forster in 1838. Zhejiang's main manufacturing sectors are electromechanical industries, textiles, chemical industries, food, and construction materials. In recent years Zhejiang's agriculture and forestry developed rapidly under the strategy of "the rich soil, fine grains."

During the early years, MCA also manufactured discs for other companies including Paramount, Disney and Warner Bros. A subsidiary of United Artists called United Artists Records briefly existed from 1956 to 1958. As United Artists Records it released mostly classical music recordings.

In southeast Europe agrarian societies first appeared in the 7th millennium BC, attested by one of the earliest farming sites of Europe, discovered in central Greece. The Bronze Age

The term Bronze Age is a relatively recent one in archaeology where its usage is largely restricted to refer to periods predating the iron and steel age. The beginning of the Bronze Age is conventionally set at approximately 3200 to 2800 BC.

The Bronze Age was originally distinguished by the relative abundance of its artifacts found in open sites such as cemeteries, which were largely abandoned for the Iron Age due to the lack of necessary fuel, as well as the more utilitarian nature of the bronzes employed in the Middle East at the time. Knowledge, for Popper, was objective, both in the sense that it is objectively true (or truthlike), and also in the sense that it has no history, is independent of experience. The only history allowed to it is that of the "evidential" verification that is the function of science. For Popper (1945) historical narratives such as those offered by Marxism and psychoanalysis were pseudohistory, or myth.

We now know that our knowledge is never quite objective. Some of the most important areas of scientific research, for instance genetics and sociobiology, depend for their veracity upon the existence and behavior of what might be called "intelligent agency." The very idea of "truth," which is a central component, but is never finally found, in the enterprise of science, is the "objectivity" of our knowledge. Science is truth-seeking, not truth-finding, a characteristic to which Karl Popper pointed out. In some areas of knowledge

Strict separation of powers did not operate in The United Kingdom, the political structure of which served in most instances[citation needed] as a model for the framers of the American Constitution. Instead, the Parliament of Great Britain operated on the more American system of checks and balances. In this system, executive and legislative powers are divided between the Crown and Parliament.[citation needed]

The UK political system divides executive powers between a Prime Minister as head of government and the monarch as head of state. The prime minister (currently Theresa May) and the other ministers make up the cabinet which is the Executive Council. The executive council is responsible for government.

Legislative powers in the UK are divided between the House of Commons (which includes hereditary peers who are members by right) and the House of Lords (which includes life peers who are appointed to their seats). Throughout the 14th century, French kings sought to expand their influence at the expense of the territorial holdings of the nobility. They ran into difficulties when attempting to control the Duchy of Aquitaine in southern France, controlled by the Lords of Castile. The Lords of Castile were a cadet branch of the Spanish royal family in Castile, and they continued to be allies of France after the marriage of a Castilian king to the sister of the French king. In order to defeat the lords of Aquitaine, the French king Charles VII of France married Isabella I of Castile, and in 1491 he defeated the armies of the Duchy of Aquitaine led by Joan II of Navarre at the Battle of Garigliano. This made the Castilian Crown heir to the English throne, and henceforth the power of the Spanish Hapsburgs in Catalonia diminished.

The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent of Pangaea was already in the Late Triassic, but this supercontinent disassembled by early in the Jurassic with the breakup of Pangea into Laurasia and Gondwana. Gondwana began to break up in the Late Triassic. Africa and South America began to separate from India, Madagascar, Antarctica, and Australia in the Early Jurassic. In the Middle Jurassic, Antarctica began to break away from Gondwana, and the North Atlantic and South Atlantic separated in the Late Jurassic and early Cretaceous. Madagascar, Antarctica, Australia, and India began to separate from the supercontinent of Gondwana. In the later Jurassic and Early Cretaceous, the Karoo Basin in South Africa was beginning to become an interior ocean

Many ground crew at the airport work at the aircraft. A tow tractor pulls the aircraft to one of the airbridges, The ground power unit is connected to the wingtip via a mobile power mast. The tow tractor is then disconnected and the aircraft is pulled onto the stand.

Aircraft stand design
The basic design of the aircraft stand is used for all classes of aircraft up to and including the DHC-8 Dash 8.

For larger aircraft, with landing gears on the nose (e.g. Boeing 737 and Airbus A320 series or 757) a different type of aircraft stand is used. At the front of the aircraft, the nose stands consists of a hydraulic ram that pushes the aircraft nose upwards such that the nose wheel is raised off the ground and the aircraft stands on its tail. The nose stands are driven and controlled by hydraulic rams. As the aircraft stands, the nose stands are lowered, and the nose wheel is lowered to touch the ground.

The highest position in Islam, caliphate, was claimed by the sultans starting since Murad I, which was established as Ottoman Caliphate since 1517 until it was abolished in 1924. The title of “Sultan of Islam” was given to the first three Ottoman sultans of the dynasty, Suleiman the Magnificent, Selim II, and Mehmed the Conqueror respectively. Sultan also used to refer to the ruler of a large part—for instance from Baghdad to Bengal—of the Islamic lands or Islam. The position was abolished and replaced by president after the formation of the Turkish Republic in 1923. It has resurrected in the modern Republic of Turkey on 3 November 1922, in the early days of the republic. Ottoman caliphate was named as The Ottoman Caliphate by contemporary sources which began after 1389. During the time of its existence, there were eleven Ottoman Caliphs. The area now called Galicia was first inhabited by humans during the Middle Paleolithic period, and it takes its name from the Gallaeci, an early Celtic people who established villages in the area. Evidence of Celtic culture can be seen throughout the Galician countryside, especially in the numerous Roman castra (e.g. at Oia in A Mariña, Oporto in Pontevedra, or at Castalla, Valbate or Peredo in Ourense).

The first major Roman settlements in the region were founded during the 4th century under Emperor Diocletian in A Rocha (or Aurea, meaning Gold), on the coast. It housed the imperial mints and was connected to other ports by roads. Galicians were heavily involved in this, both in the administration of the Roman Empire and in the trade and administration of the products of the mines that sprang up in the area. Birds have a very efficient system for diffusing oxygen into the blood; birds have a ten times greater surface area to gas exchange volume than mammals. But as birds also tend to have a lower metabolism, there is a limit to how thin you can make the bird – but there is also a limit in which thick birds should not get.

Birds have three lungs: one for oxygen and two for carbon dioxide. At high altitude the oxygen levels are extremely low and so the birds need to compensate by reducing their resting metabolism. There is little point having two lungs when one of them will just be used by air: the lungs are kept full of air to avoid the bird drowning at altitude. A high metabolic rate burns lots of oxygen, and if you are a bird, this means a high metabolic rate makes you inefficient. In fact birds on the wing are so efficient they have a limited range for efficiency because of the limited supply of oxygen at altitude.

Vladimir had been prince of Novgorod when his father Sviatoslav I died in 972. He was forced to flee to Scandinavia, where he remained until 988 before returning to become grand prince of Kiev. As with so many of the Viking raiders who terrorized Russia, Vladimir was actually quite religious and sought to preserve the established ritual and forms of worship within his community. In fact, he took one Christian wife, Theodora, a granddaughter of Byzantine ruler Nicephorus Phocas.

Vladimir's Christianization policy succeeded, and his capital of Kiev became the religious center of Rus lands: its Greek Orthodox clergy even traveled to Constantinople to receive education from Byzantium. And from this nucleus, the Russian Orthodox Church was eventually built.

Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle. For most, the search for identity begins in the adolescent years. During these years, adolescents are constantly trying to define themselves—to understand what they like, do, and believe about a wide variety of topics.
This stage is often regarded as the time when adolescents become more interested in their own "self-concepts" and begin to become involved in peer groups or sports, as a means of trying to find their identity. This self-searching leads them to form and accept or reject sets of values and beliefs; for example, a young man interested in being a police officer may believe a policeman should exhibit honesty, kindness, and courage.
Adolescents may also experience difficulties in constructing identity that may cause feelings of confusion. In trying to sort out the contradictory feelings and desires they experience, many adolescents try to sort out which ones are more important to them. Egocentrism in adolescents forms a self-conscious desire to feel important in their peer groups and enjoy social acceptance. Unlike the conflicting aspects of egocentrism in younger children, however, the adolescent egocentrism is not necessarily based on a childish desire for popularity or material goods. It is often expressed more in an interest in and desire to conform with peer groups, to do the right thing and be seen doing it, and to express moral standards that are shared by their peer group. In adolescent egocentrism, concern with popularity, and the desire to act as if one is important (i.e., to perform in public and to please others), are in part a way of making a strong statement about the self and showing off one's accomplishments, but they are generally not done to win approval or acceptance by others. Stanley Schachter formulated his theory on the earlier work of a Spanish physician, Gregorio Marañón, who injected patients with epinephrine via an aerosol inhaler and suggested that this mechanism might be useful in asthma therapy in 1930. Because epinephrine was an adrenocortical hormone, Schachter believed that this approach ought to be safe, with low systemic side effects. It was not a cure for asthma, but Schachter wrote that it "gives marked and immediate improvement in the respiratory difficulty of almost all the patients treated." In a follow-up study, Schachter reported that some patients on the inhalation form of the hormone found relief even when they stopped injections, due to continued aerosol exposure, "thus adding to earlier hopes for bronchial asthma being a disease of the reversible type."

Hong Taiji's bureaucracy was staffed with many Han Chinese, including many newly surrendered Ming officials. The Manchus' continued dominance was ensured by the use of the Qigong system. The Manchu system of administration was based on strict adherence to hierarchy, which ensured that Han commoners were kept in their place and out of Manchu affairs. The use of the Qigong system was important because the Confucian scholar-bureaucrats were allowed in to play a bureaucratic role, but their role was restricted to minor affairs. The importance of the Qigong system was to keep the Manchu bureaucracy out of the running of military affairs, while simultaneously allowing the Han commoners to keep their civil rights. Many of these Han commoners had joined the Manchu civil bureaucracy out of financial reward and were quite successful, holding higher civil service status than the Manchus. Y DNA studies tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths. In most Jewish populations, these founders could have been drawn primarily from either an Ethiopian or a Levantine source, depending on the migration pathway pursued at the time. Although the two migration pathways would not be mutually exclusive, it is more likely that both the Ethiopian and the Levantine populations would have contributed to the overall Jewish genetic diversity as well as to the Ashkenazi gene pool.

The study of autosomal DNA (atDNA) markers from Jewish communities around the world could shed important light on these questions. An international consortium known as the Jewish Genome Diversity project recently published a comprehensive atDNA study of more than 1,600 individuals from 70 populations in 14 different countries representing about 85% of the world's Jewish population (The Jewish Genome Consortium [@CR52]).

The state united behind the Plan of Ayutla and ratified the new constitution in 1855. The state was able to survive through the Reform War of 1857, the French Intervention in 1862 and the Glorious Revolution of 1871. In 1901, the state joined the Federal Republic of Central America; in 1921, Teposcolula was admitted as a state in the Mexican Federation. In 1931, General Abelardo L. Rodríguez established the National Revolutionary Party in this state.

In contemporary society, adolescents also face some risks as their sexuality begins to transform. While some of these, such as emotional distress (fear of abuse by a sexual partner, or of physical health effects such as HIV or pregnancy) are similar to those faced by adults, others are distinctive to this population and arise from issues common to adolescence, such as school problems or the pressure to do well in exams. The latter risk factor is thought to arise from the need of adolescents to seek sexual partners to facilitate their passing the next stage in life – i.e. adulthood.

Sexual maturity

Sexual maturity is an individual concept varying across cultures, but generally involves physiological changes that allow reproduction to occur.  Among the indicators of sexual maturity are: 
 increased growth of secondary sex characteristics
 increased sexual arousal 
 regular menarche or menopause, or other signs of the reawakening and slowing of the sexual cycle.

However, sexual maturity does not always entail sexual activity

The deeper ancestral demography of Bermuda's population has been obscured by the ethnic homogenisation of the last four centuries. There is effectively no ethnic heterogeneity now, but in the past all but ~1% of the population were of a single ethnic group (sub-Saharan African), which was replaced by a colonising group from a different continent.

Although Bermuda was settled by the British (a new nation rather than a new ethnic group), the African-British mixture has continued to evolve in the last 450+ years into a new distinct genetic sub-population.

Some of these changes can be explained by genetic drift, but the large changes that happened on the island are probably related to a severe population bottleneck, which happened during and after the slave trade.

The body’s capability to react to antigen depends on a person's age, antigen type, maternal factors and the area where the antigen is presented. If a vaccine’s antigen is matched to that which the body is capable of fighting, then a person will have a positive response.

This is why it is so important to understand what factors will affect response if one happens to be suffering from an autoimmune disease. Even if this does happen, there are some treatment options for autoimmune diseases that can increase the likelihood of a positive response if injected with certain vaccines.

As a person’s immune system ages, cells tend to slowly lose the ability to produce antibodies and react to various antigens. If a person has an autoimmune disease, then their cells would also be affected by the inflammatory process. A government report covered by the Guardian in 2002 indicates that between 1940 and 1979, the Ministry of Defence "turned large parts of the country into a giant experiment in the use and abuse of poisons, and the contamination of food and water supplies".

It has long been established that a number of these chemicals were highly toxic. The MoD's policy was that the tests on animals did not have to be carried out before human experiments, because the human experiments were regarded merely as safety checks. During the 1950s, 60,000 chemical and biological substances were tested on tens of thousands of animals.

The Ministry's tests were carried out in a network of specially constructed compounds. In addition to standard government and military locations, the chemicals were used on a farm at Porton Down. The farm was leased by the Ministry of Defence, and the farmer was paid by the Ministry. According to reports at the time, the Ministry was in thrall to the power and influence of its chief chemical scientists

Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it into their digestive tracts as uric acid or urates, without involving significant amounts of ammonia and urea production as in mammals. Birds typically ingest ammonia-rich foods such as worms and crustaceans and then perform the required ammonia metabolism themselves. They use a combination of the uricolytic pathway of the reptiles and the ammonotelic system of the fish.

In addition to the aforementioned roles of the kidneys, in ectotherms the elimination of nitrogenous wastes by the kidneys is complemented by that in other body tissues. Thus, some of the nitrogenous wastes are excreted from the kidney into the bladder, while the rest enter into the body tissues along with the bloodstream. Regarding the timing of German rapprochement, many historians agree that the dismissal of Maxim Litvinov, whose Jewish ethnicity was viewed unfavorably by the Nazis as he was a former employee of the Russian Empire, as Soviet ambassador to Germany in 1937 proved to be the main turning point in terms of German-Soviet relations as Hitler perceived that this had been a personal insult from Stalin. However, this perception was not confirmed or acknowledged in public. After initial attempts to be reconciled failed in 1939, relations became more strained when the Soviet Union signed a Non-Aggression Pact with Germany on 23 August 1939. The Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact of the same day marked the end of Russian neutrality in the face of the German-Polish war, with secret protocols dividing up Poland between Germany and the Soviet Union.

When Nintendo released the NES in the US, the design styling was deliberately different from that of other game consoles. Nintendo wanted to distinguish its product from its predecessors, as its name was often associated with arcade quality games, which were not as popular as home consoles. Hence, Nintendo used the "flipper" cartridge system instead of the more conventional cartridge system used by Sega and the Atari 2600. The system also did not use plastic game cartridges like its competitors used, but rather cartridges made of steel. Another unusual aspect was that the controller contained only two buttons: a Start and Select button. Despite these unusual aspects, the design was very popular with video game enthusiasts, which led to the Nintendo Entertainment System becoming highly successful. These early video game consoles, Nintendo included, all used a similar controller design until 1995; the Nintendo 64 used a controller with similar design style.

In the basic ladder match, the only object for each to do is to win each of any number of individual matches between the two players, and the number of matches required to win increases as the ladders advance. A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing. Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way, only a true predator is physically and genetically suited to consume another living organism. That means not every predator we see around us is necessarily a threat to human life, but it has to be something with at least some level of that genetic makeup. This has been a point brought up in discussions before, including in this one.

There are exceptions to this, of course.

Such as an animal who may have the instincts and drive to eat someone, but who would suffer from some sort of genetic abnormality that wouldn't be compatible with humans. Or a creature that has been forced into a life of predation at a very young age that is now incapable of feeding on anything but humans.

The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, signed on February 2, 1848, by American diplomat Nicholas Trist and Mexican plenipotentiary representatives Luis G. Cuevas and Francisco Mújica y Maestro, effectively ended hostilities between Mexico and the United States by exchanging ownership of land to the Rio Grande in the US north of Nueces River and the Colorado River in Mexico. However, it also ceded Mexican lands to the US that stretched a full three times the size of the combined territories of Wyoming, Vermont, and Connecticut in the northwestern portion of Texas, from present-day El Paso up to the vicinity of the New Mexico-Texas border.[11] The latter portions were never incorporated into the United States and instead formed the Mexican province of Tejas (Texas) under Mexican rule. Because it transferred ownership of land that was not yet in US jurisdiction, the treaty was called a "treaty of conquest".[12]

The Royal Assent ceremony takes place in the Senate, as the sovereign is traditionally barred from the House of Commons. On the day of the event, the Lords are summoned to the Chamber of the House in order to listen to the Sovereign’s speech and to see the Royal Assent being given.

The Royal Assent is a formal approval by the Queen for a new Act of Parliament to become law. It is not an approval for the content of the Act but simply confirms its approval for this process for that Act.

In accordance to the 1706 Act (which had been passed since the last Royal Assent ceremony), Queen’s Speech in the House of Commons is written as a written statement of Her Majesty’s Government in response to the Prime Minister’s Speech in the House of Commons which outlines the Government’s agenda.

Sound could be stored in either analog or digital format and in a variety of surround sound formats; NTSC discs could carry two analog audio tracks, plus two PCM audio tracks, for a total of 16 discrete or continuous program audio channels.  However, not all programs were recorded with all of these channels, and not all systems were able to reproduce them all.  In addition to the surround sound channels, analog NTSC had five program audio channels (L, C, R, LFE, and Surround EX) and three audio subcarriers (CC1, CC2, and CC3).  These were either derived directly from the composite video signal, or extracted from it by the video processor (decoder).

NTSC used the FM, suppressed carrier method to transmit its audio-only program audio signals.  The FM sound was added to the NTSC video signal in analog form and broadcast over VHF band I (channels 2, 3, 4 and 5).

From his diagrams of a small number of particles interacting in spacetime, Feynman could then model all of physics in terms of the spins of those particles and the rules for their interactions. These were not the rules of conventional classical physics—no laws, formulas, or equations—for there was nothing but a single "all-inclusive law" for nature, known as the "Uncertainty Principle."

It meant that the more precisely a particle could be predicted to be at any particular point in spacetime at a certain moment, the less the knowledge one had about the position and speed of every other particle in the universe. Because it was fundamentally impossible to measure and predict more precisely than this, the Uncertainty Principle implied that it was always more probable that two particles exist in this or that region of space at such-and-such a time interval than a particle is at another location right that very moment.

The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem. Self-esteem is defined as one's thoughts and feelings about one's self-concept and abilities, feelings of self-worth, and self-respect. Self-esteem has a great impact on one's behaviors and thoughts throughout adulthood. It is one's level of confidence, or security, within themselves and their surroundings. High self-esteem or low self-esteem can make or break a person's emotional and social experience. People with low self-esteem may become victims of bullying or rejection by peers, which creates lifelong scars within their psyche. High self-esteem is usually associated with happiness and self-confidence. In terms of a young person's identity, being able to look out for oneself is important and can form if the young person feels secure in themselves.

Constantius, ordered Liberius into exile in 356 giving him, then, three days to comply. He was ordered into banishment to Beroea in Mesopotamia (today Aleppo). Liberius and his friends tried to persuade Constantius to change

The Montana Territory was formed on April 26, 1864, when the U.S. passed the Organic Act. Schools started forming in the area before it became a territory, and in 1862, Congress had approved the establishment of the Territorial University at Helena, which would offer instruction in the law, medicine, dentistry, and engineering. The Territorial University was to be the first of the land-grant universities established under an 1854 federal law that was passed during the presidency of Franklin Pierce (1840–1856). The Act "for the support of colleges" allowed the federal government to provide land to states for the creation of educational institutions. The land would be used to pay for instruction in the sciences and trades, and the state would provide land and funding for the education of "teachers of common schools." On 20 June 1794, Burke received a vote of thanks from the Commons for his services in the Hastings Trial and he immediately resigned his seat, being elected on 10 July as one of two MPs for Essex. He refused to stand for election in 1796, although he was urged to do so in both directions by supporters. He believed the election would be tainted by his trial and his previous opposition to Hastings. In 1800 he tried unsuccessfully to gain the county's other seat.

Later career

Having given up his Commons seat, he continued to be active in politics, including writing some speeches and a book. In 1800, he was elected as one of two MPs for Surrey, but died in November 1800. After his death, his son, Richard, unsuccessfully stood for his father's seat at the 1801 and 1802 general elections. In 1799 he was elected High Sheriff of Essex.

The nation almost immediately fell into civil war that involved various factions fighting one another; these factions were often distinguished by clan loyalties. More than 500 years old, a republican form of government was adopted as France became a constitutional monarchy in the late 18th century. During the 19th century the country became known as the “world’s foremost political laboratory,” a place of constant reforms and new beginnings. A series of crises at the end of the century ultimately yielded a chaotic and violent empire in which a weary populace was not keen to participate: the First World War was fought mostly in French colonies. Paris, however, remained the center of European culture and, after the war, cultural life reached heights greater than ever.

The university has also been able to attract political figures to its faculty and administration, including presidents, senators, congressmen, and governors.

Jean Macfarlane founded the University of California, Berkeley's Institute of Human Development, formerly called the Institute of Child Welfare, in 1927. The institute was originally a place for working mothers and their children. Macfarlane saw the need for infant, child, and adult care during the World War II and the Depression. Macfarlane saw many families in need and wanted to bring the community together as one to support them. The Berkeley Foundation of Women gave Macfarlane the resources to start the first free childcare program in the country.

Though Britain and the empire emerged victorious from the Second World War, the effects of the conflict were profound, both at home and abroad. Much of continental Europe had been devastated by aerial bombardment, causing immense casualties and the loss of much of its infrastructure. The war left Britain with a huge deficit in manufacturing capacity, much of which had to be replaced with imported raw materials, machinery and consumer goods. New industries based on coal and petrochemicals were developed to make up the shortfall. Despite this, the period from the end of the war to the mid-1950s was one of relative social and economic stability, and a period of low inflation.

The new technologies developed in Britain, notably jet engines, nuclear energy, and computers, were not widely utilised at first, and were applied to military use in the immediate post-war era. Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and complex, both during and after training. The molecular mechanisms underlying recognition memory formation have been thoroughly investigated, and memory impairment is known to be closely related to the activation or inhibition of specific genes in certain brain circuits. By contrast, how and where synaptic changes in neurons are induced and maintained over time remain relatively unclear.[@b3-ndt-11-1047] The brain contains over 100 billion neurons that provide its essential functions through an integrated communication network. The synapse is the site at which such communication normally occurs. The synapse must therefore contain a cellular and molecular machinery that regulates, and which is responsible for, synaptic transmission and synaptic plasticity. This machinery comprises postsynaptic proteins (neuron-specific receptors; transporters, second messenger pathways, channels), synaptic vesicle proteins, cytoskeletal components, and pre- and postsynaptic trafficking proteins. A common way in which emotions are conceptualized in sociology is in terms of the multidimensional characteristics including cultural or emotional labels (e.g., happiness, anxiety, anger), feelings (i.e., positive or negative), and dispositions (i.e., emotional dispositions include trait like happiness or pessimism). For instance, happiness is a state that is characterized by positive feelings, and a set of personality traits that are part of emotional dispositions, such as the tendency to experience positive affect (Mauss et al. 2017). Emotional dispositions are also conceptualized as stable traits, in which people differ from one another as a result of their biology, biology + personal history, or their individual experience. Darwin was hard at work on his "big book" on Natural Selection, when on 18 June 1858 he received a parcel from Wallace, who had just moved from Down to London. "I cannot tell you," Darwin wrote in his diary, "how delighted I was at this most surprising and kind remembrance." Wallace, ever modest, had sent him an abridged version of his essay on Natural Selection as something "kind to send to a lonely fellow in a distant land."

Darwin had been working on this theory for fifteen years, but it would not be published until 1859. The next time he saw Wallace, Darwin asked about the origins of the idea. Wallace recounted how he had been sitting in his window one evening idly watching a beetle, when the thought came to him that "if one could observe [animals and plants] exhibiting every action as they really do, when left to themselves, nothing would seem simpler than to account for each." Early Modern universities initially continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages: natural philosophy, logic, medicine, theology, mathematics, astronomy (and astrology), music, and some practical aspects of agriculture. By the 14th century, as the universities expanded beyond Paris, Oxford, and Bologna, so these fields came to be organized into faculties ( _facultas_ ), each composed of several chairs (literally seats that professors occupied).

What characterizes the modern university from the very beginning is the idea that all knowledge is to be pursued through systematic inquiry and discovery ( _invenire_, Latin for "to seek out"). A _magister_ (from Latin _magister_, "master," "mistress," or "teacher") is a teacher whose subject matter has been prescribed for all students. Professorships were then "created," not inherited, and therefore were often more closely connected to particular political or religious interests than to the general advancement of knowledge.

The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only. A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend the articles of incorporation (charter). Members of this kind of organization hold or own shares and elect both executive and non-executive officers of the corporation. In a board-only corporation, the board elects the president, executive officers, and non-executive officers, and the members hold all shares.

In addition to these two types, there is the hybrid business association, which is essentially a board-only organization in that the elected board is the governing body. However, the association structure permits business people to own an interest in the association, which, in turn, owns the business. Such individuals may also sit on the board and elect executive officers as well as elect members, but only associate members may participate in the vote for the board.

The major advantage of the membership corporation is its flexibility. Members decide the policies

The nature of biblical punishment is specified in the Bible. For instance, the New Testament calls for "restitution" for wrongs committed—which could mean repairing damage or providing repayment of the person wronged. Many cultures define the transition into adultlike sexuality by specific biological or social milestones in an adolescent's life. For example, menarche (the onset of menstruation) marks the beginning of childbearing in women, and adolescent marriage and childbearing are often associated with social and economic transitions. A critical role of adolescence appears to be to renegotiate parental control, with the adolescent developing a sense of autonomy. This autonomy, in turn, enables him or her to experience a sense of ownership of his or her self. The adolescent's experience of ownership permits the development of intimacy.

A second developmental task of adolescence is to separate from the previous child/parent roles as an identity develops and becomes more inclusive. This new sense of identity involves a rejection of childhood and a shift from childishness to adult behavior; this is called "adulthood." The process of individuation is the process of the separation of identity and individuation from the parents.

Since re-establishing independence, Estonia has styled itself as the gateway between East and West and aggressively pursued economic reform and integration with the West. Estonia has become famous for high standards of living and an advanced technological infrastructure to back that up. The country is well known for its modern and clean environment as well as the country's e-solutions and innovations. Furthermore, Estonia has been moving from military production to high-tech defense solutions and cyber security.

The country's major export industries include pharmaceutical products, paper and cardboard, transportation equipment and machinery, and rubber and plastics. As it grows more prosperous, it will continue to attract foreign investment.

In terms of the political environment, Estonia faces no threats from its neighbors and has an exemplary level of stability and security. It is an open society with a free press, and the government is highly committed to encouraging the free flow of information. Estonia has the highest level of Internet penetration in the region.

The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire. Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as "invasions," they often entailed very little fighting. Even in Britain, which appears to have had the best set of fortifications in Western Europe, the Romans simply made a symbolic entry once every year.

###   **Early Middle Ages**

The new political units that emerged after the fall of the Roman Empire are the "barbarian kingdoms," which tended to be ruled by a group of cousins and were sometimes even divided among different branches of the same family, so that at any given time half a dozen different kings would be claiming their rightful places. These kingdoms were very unstable, especially in the north of France, where small kingdoms constantly fought one another for territory and wealth. Comprehensive schools have been accused of grade inflation after a study revealed that Gymnasium senior students of average mathematical ability found themselves at the very bottom of a class full of other Gymnasium students who were significantly less capable, German newspaper Der Westen reported on May 4.The study was based on a mathematics examination made in 2005 at Gymnasium Niederkruechten, which is a secondary school in the Bavarian town of Bad Kötzting. It was revealed this week that on average only 4% of Gymnasium students scored at least 5.1 out of 7, while almost 28% of the class took an exam with a grade between 3.8 and 5.1. The same applied to grades between 3.6 and 5.0, with almost 40% from this class taking this kind of exam.At the lower end of the exam grading scale, only 11.6% in the group scored lower than 3.0.

The university culture developed differently in northern Europe than it did in the south, although the northern (primarily Germany, France and Great Britain) and southern (primarily Italy, the Low Countries and Spain) universities experienced similar growth through the 16th and early 17th centuries. (The Dutch word universiteit, used in the 16th century, probably originally meant ‘teaching university’.) For example, the Jesuit University of Coimbra in Portugal was created by Pope Paul III in 1537 and is often seen as marking the start of the university experience as we recognise it. It was to remain a European model of a teaching university for many years, but it had no formal links to the academic world except for the involvement of its members.

Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. A clinical sample is placed on or in the medium, and the medium is incubated under conditions favoring growth of the agent. If the agent is present, it will multiply giving a positive culture.
A variety of procedures have been developed to increase the sensitivity of detecting microorganisms in a sample. The ideal technique would be one that gave a positive result for every positive specimen and a negative result for every negative specimen. The sensitivity (percent of positive specimens detected) and the specificity (percent of negative specimens correctly identified as negative or not containing the target organism) of the test procedure help determine its value for a particular application. The sensitivity and specificity are, of course, interrelated, so that an increase in one will result in a decrease in the other.

The current Mac product family uses Intel x86-64 processors. Apple introduced an emulator during the transition from PowerPC chips (called Rosetta), and then dropped it when the "native" 64-bit architecture hit. "Apple is now completely 64-bit, we don't have a Rosetta" Jobs said. One theory goes that the 64-bit chips don't have the same architectural hooks built in to help with Rosetta; if your app were being developed today, it wouldn't need Rosetta.

Jobs then went on to outline his hopes for future Mac hardware, adding that "we're going to focus on speed. I think Intel's great, and it's going to work out great."

The current Mac line runs on a trio of processors: the 1.2GHz iMac; 1.5GHz Mac Mini; and two Mac Pros ranging from 3.2GHz to 3.33GHz. All three CPUs contain dual-core architecture.

While medieval pageants and festivals such as Corpus Christi were church-sanctioned, Carnival was also a manifestation of medieval folk culture. These traditional celebrations are a rich source of ideas and cultural expressions that can help in the revival of festivals in our daily lives.

Carnival, a celebration at once both secular and sacred, is the central event of the year in the Catholic countries like Italy, Spain, Portugal, Poland, etc. It is a festival where people of both high and low class, men and women, people of all levels of wealth and leisure gather to enjoy merry-making. In India also (and there too on a small scale), it is celebrated in various places.

Carnival is held annually from the evening of December 26th to Ash Wednesday, beginning with the Feast of the Name of Our Lord Jesus Christ the Most Blessed.

The theme of the festival may vary according to the local customs, but the elements are identical

Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much control and tend to over-assert rather than defuse conflicts. By the late teens, they start to exercise their power of choice and to demand greater freedom. But the very rapid physical changes of puberty, and the need to maintain some sort of sexual identity within a group, inhibit this process and often block it completely. These young men and women are still emotionally dependent on parents who are often anxious to help them and find them in an awkward position.

Sigmund Freud argued that adolescents go through a rite of passage which is both sexual and emotional: they need to rid themselves of parental control, and at the same time they are in an emotional state where they can be easily upset. The late 1980s saw a series of liberalising economic reforms within Libya designed to cope with the decline in oil revenues. In May 1987, Gaddafi was appointed Chairman of the General People's Committee (GPC), effectively Libya's new federal government. In July, in response to the loss of key revenue streams and in order to counterbalance the growing power of foreign interest in Libya's natural resources, the Libyan Investment Authority (LIA) was created. In 1990, the government passed Law 42, which provided for private ownership of much of the previously state-owned industry and gave foreign companies direct access to Libya's markets. The aim of this process was to encourage "more active participation of citizens in the national economy with equitable distribution of wealth and ownership of economic resources between themselves."

A 2010 study on Jewish ancestry by Atzmon-Ostrer et al. stated "Two major groups were identified by principal component, phylogenetic, and multidimensional scaling analysis: a non-Ashkenazi and an Ashkenazi group" and this study does not mention the Khazars. An earlier genome-wide DNA study (2011) concluded that there are "two major Jewish groups, the Ashkenazi and the non-Ashkenazi Jews with large shared genetic similarities... which supports their common origin."

Genome research
The Y-chromosome, passed from father to son, carries genetic information found in human males only. If non-Jewish males who have had Y-chromosomes inherited from Jews, and thus have a gene passed from Jews to them, then Jews can be found among their male descendants. This is sometimes called the Khazars to Ashkenazis model, or the Cohen Modal Haplotype for the Cohen Modal Haplotype.

Marshall Field & Company originated in 1852. It was the premier department store on the main shopping street in the Midwest, State Street in Chicago. In the 1950s and 1960s, the store ranked at the top in store revenue. It was located in Chicago and offered an array of goods. The store closed in 1995.

History

Origin
Marshall Field founded his business with a $50 deposit and the sale of a watch, a knife, a pair of socks, and a few handkerchiefs. With cash in hand he and his wife traveled to St. Louis to open a dry goods store. Upon arrival Marshall's wife became pregnant, and so Marshall left the store in the care of his father-in-law, Joseph Medill, and returned to New York. Joseph built the business into a strong, stable firm. He died in 1856; Marshall returned and the business thrived until Chicago's growth as a city prompted a move.

In response to the early-to-mid-17th century "continental rationalism" John Locke (1632–1704) proposed in 1689 his _Essay Concerning Human Understanding_. The work is a philosophical and empirical treatise on man and cognition. A pioneer in epistemology and philosophy of mind and a chief representative of empiricist philosophy, Locke is celebrated particularly for his theory of language, which is built upon the thesis that human knowledge is the result of empirical experience and the senses. The _Essay_ develops a position that would become known as "tabula rasa" (blank slate) epistemology; that is, Locke's theory of cognition and epistemology makes a sharp division (and thereby demarcates sharply) between the innate knowledge (information carried in the brain) as contrasted with the knowledge derived from experience via the senses, that is, _tabula_ or the slate of the mind on which all of our knowledge is written by our experience

Before forming Queen, Brian May and Roger Taylor had played together in a band named Smile. Freddie Mercury (then known by his birth name of Farrokh Bulsara) joined the band not long after Brian and Roger had asked him to join, having originally come to London with the intention of becoming a taxicab driver. In Smile, Brian, Roger and Freddie played guitar, piano, bass and drums, while session singers Vince Mc-Gill, Mary Arden and Rosetta Hightower performed vocals. This line-up went through several guises and the band was signed to RCA Records before Brian left in 1975 shortly after the release of their debut album. Although Freddie remained with the group, Roger and Brian began to work separately from Freddie for a time, before finally deciding to go it alone with the formation of Queen. The men's basketball team has over 1,600 wins, one of only 12 schools who have reached that mark, and have appeared in 28 NCAA tournaments and the national championship game in 1976. During the 2012–13 season, UCLA set a school record for most combined wins against ranked opponents in a season, with 23 victories in a streak dating back to 1997. The Bruins have posted 15 top-ten national rankings in a span of 26 seasons in the polls.

For men's volleyball, the team is among the most successful in NCAA history. The team set a school record in consecutive season for the national championship in the 2015, 2017 and 2019 seasons, earning a total of 25 consecutive major conference titles. Since 1976, UCLA is tied with Princeton for third all-time in all-time NCAA Tournament wins with 108, trailing only UCLA's rival, USC with 121 and Stanford with 115.

Homer refers to the "Hellenes" (/ˈhɛliːnz/) as a relatively small tribe settled in Thessaly and mentioned several times in the Iliad, and the people of Troy when they were under the control of the Achaeans. Some scholars believe that Homer's use of the term "Hellenes" refers to the Greeks as a nationality in general, and not solely to Greek-speaking peoples or the Greeks in the geographic or ethnic sense. Homer makes several references to the city of Hellas and to a river which flows through its plain. Other references to Hellas are either indirect or refer to a geographic region, but in most cases the actual locations or homelands remain uncertain. An indirect reference to the land of the Hellenes appears in the Odyssey. Many, though not all, modern scholars interpret it as a reference to the geographical Greek peninsula, rather than to the Greek peoples living outside it.

Under the Capetian dynasty France slowly began to expand its authority over the nobility, growing out of the Île-de-France to exert control over territory which, during the Hundred Years' War, had belonged to the English crown. In 1438, a parliament was created and the king agreed to hold off from attacking the English on his wife's side of the Channel. Further, in 1445, the French began to attack the English at sea and their first attempt at a naval war resulted in disaster. A second attempt produced the victory of the so-called Battle of Formigny in 1450.

There was also warfare between the French and the English. King Charles VIII of France attempted to claim the English throne at the beginning of Henry VII's reign. However, the battle was one-sided almost from the beginning. The reasons for this are the subject of continuing study by military strategists and academics. One possible theory was that the Spanish fleet sailed into the Bay of Biscay and was unable to turn around as night fell, leading to a slow loss of morale. Another theory is that the French vessels were in the centre of the line and when their light was put out, the Spanish fleet, in the darkness, came around to chase them. It would be a classic ambush, although the French may have lacked the military experience to pull off such a complex manoeuvre as successfully as they did. Whatever the reason, the French escaped to fight another battle.

The European concept of "race", along with many of the ideas now associated with the term, arose at the time of the scientific revolution, which introduced a new worldview derived from the ancient Greek naturalism of Aristotle. Aristotle saw humans first and foremost as parts of the natural order: he believed in transmigration into plants and other animals, and believed that there were two forms of intelligence: that with which humans are endowed by their environment and their heredity, and that by training we could come to possess more naturally, as the philosopher is able to exercise his natural intelligence more and more. Such a belief was widely held in Europe before Columbus and other discoverers sailed across the Atlantic.

The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US), contested primarily for technological superiority in spaceflight.[1][2] Both countries engaged in a technological "Space Race" for military, propaganda, and economic reasons. The Space Race is considered by many historians to be an aspect of the Cold War, although it should be distinguished from similar competition in the Cold War in other fields.[3][4][5][6] In the United States, the Space Race was linked in the public mind to the Soviet Union's launches of the Sputnik satellite in 1957, which galvanized Americans to support funding for science.

A number of U.S. officials, however, had been concerned about the Soviet Union's space progress for years before Sputnik.[7] The launch of Sputnik in 1957 prompted quick enactment of the National Aeronautics and Space Act in 1958.[8

In January 1920, Tito and his wife made a long and difficult journey home to Yugoslavia where he arrived in September. Upon his return, Broz was immediately arrested in Belgrade by the Serbian government which accused him of inciting strikes in the city, supporting the pro-Zimmermann movement that advocated Germany's return to the war and advocating the independence of Croats and Slovenes from Yugoslavia. As if this wasn't enough, the Yugoslav government also used the occasion to strip Tito of his Yugoslav citizenship, and the fact that he remained in Belgrade during his arrest meant he was put under house arrest in the city for a period of six weeks. On 5 October, Tito's imprisonment was lifted but he had already lost the support of his own party, the Yugoslav Communist Party. The Comintern, under the direction of Józef Unszlicht had withdrawn its support for his and his party's revolutionary strategy.

In surveys made in Europe and the United States, green is the color most commonly associated with nature, life, health, youth, spring, hope and new growth; in the United States, it is second only to blue.

The use of green as a political symbol has been evident at least since the 19th century, for a wide variety of political movements. The British Green Party (founded in 1993), and in various forms the Green Party of Germany, Denmark, the Netherlands, Slovakia, Norway, and several other countries were inspired by the politics of ecology and its emphasis on peace, social justice, and environmentalism.

Green may also be regarded symbolically as the colour of Islam, representing the color of Paradise and the "living" (green) things in contrast to the "dead" (inert) things of this world, hence the color of Islam.

Successful cultivation of cotton requires a long frost-free period, plenty of sunshine, and a moderate rainfall, usually from 600 to 1,200 mm (24 to 48 inches) annually. The best climates for cultivating cotton are on the river basins of the Amazon, the Nile, the Parana, and the Niger rivers in West Africa. Cotton also grows well in India, China, the United States, and parts of Latin America. However, the best climate is undoubtedly that of Texas, with an average rainfall of approximately 3,000 mm (118 inches) and an average growing season of 220 to 230 days. It is estimated that over 1,500,000 hectares (3,710,000 acres) in the United States are devoted to cotton farming.

The latter, however, depends on accurate diagnosis, which in turn requires appropriate diagnostic methods. However, this has not always been accomplished. Only since the introduction of PCR and its various modified versions has it become possible to diagnose almost any microbial entity, even in very low quantities. Nevertheless, the sensitivity and the specificity of a given method is dependent on the clinical question, the chosen specimen type, and possible laboratory contaminations.

In October 2014, the trial of six senior staff and journalists at The Sun newspaper began. All six were charged with conspiring to commit misconduct in a public office, though this charge was later dropped. A seventh individual, former managing editor Geoff Webster, pleaded guilty to a charge of conspiracy to commit misconduct in a public office, and was sentenced to 20 months’ imprisonment. The others were acquitted or found not guilty.

The UK government brought the case against the former managers for their publication of the voicemail from Milly Dowler’s phone in July 2002, which suggested that she might have been murdered, a crime for which a local man had later been convicted. The initial military maneuvers began in September 1806. In a notable letter to Marshal Soult detailing the plan for the campaign, Napoleon described the essential features of his strategy: "Our troops will leave a large body of men, perhaps 100,000, in Spain and another of the same size in Italy. From this base, our armies will strike at Austria from the north and north east, while our Italian allies will operate from a base in the south west, as before. I suggest for the base of operations in Spain that we do not attack Portugal; it would be better not to divide our forces and keep half the army in Spain. I am anxious to send some troops to Russia against Britain to keep my right flank open.... All this, with some diversion on the side of Egypt and the Orient, should enable us to strike down on Austria's flank in the spring time."

The Russian campaign would be designed to destroy British sea power by seizing her Baltic islands.

With respect to these outer regions, the Qing maintained imperial control, with the emperor acting as Mongol khan, patron of Tibetan Buddhism and protector of the Gelug sect as well as Tibetan culture. While Mongol power declined under the Yuan, who reorganized society along Chinese lines, the Qing retained the old pattern of the "dual monarchy," combining imperial and Mongol-Tibetan rule. Even their Manchu ancestors, the Jurchens, remained on the Tibetan borderlands to protect the Mongol Yelu tribes against Mongolian and Tibetan encroachment. In the sixteenth century, the Qing continued to rule from Koko Nor (in present-day China) and were still recognized as the sovereigns of Tibet from 1642 to 1720. Jefferson and James Madison's conceptions of separation have long been debated. Jefferson refused to issue Proclamations of Thanksgiving sent to him by Congress for fear of aligning with the Federalist party and later because he believed that government should avoid all "disposition to give our own citizens an artificial superiority over others" by calling public attention to "the sense which we entertain of the goodness of God in placing us in this new world, with all the necessary means of enjoying, (...) the greatest portion of human happiness." After a meeting with Madison and others, Jefferson reportedly announced that he could "as President no more pray for the conversion of any nation by my official exertions than I could as a private individual." Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a role different from his or her given role. An individual who takes on an active identity as a parent and spouse becomes the partner, not the parent. A woman may decide to enter an exclusive community made up of black, Catholic women only, and exclude others (such as Muslims or non-Catholics).

In some groups the exclusiveness of boundaries is reinforced by religious practice. When there is a strong group loyalty within a group, the group membership of the individual becomes more salient than its non-membership. Exclusive boundaries between the members may then be seen as a way for the group to protect its unique identity. In such situations, the existence of non-members is not seen as a threat to the group's distinctiveness.

To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably nocturnal, early synapsids like _Megazostrodon_, and even later forms like dicynodonts and gorgonopsians, had developed to give birth to precocial offspring, meaning they were fully mobile on day one. Gorgonopsians were smallish beasts, but a much enlarged _Morganucodon_, reaching up to a metre in length, showed that some early synapsids had become much larger, although very little is known about how they did so. Some later forms, too, such as _Pamelina_, the largest known synapsid ever, and _Tachiraptor_, a giant, bipedal predator of the Early Permian, may have had body sizes approaching that of a rhinoceros.

The relationships adolescents have with their peers, family, and members of their social sphere play a vital role in the social development of an adolescent. As an individual matures, he or she is able to adapt to society in a way that is productive. Without stable relationships, this process of adaption would be hindered and thus make an individual less likely to fully integrate into society.  Furthermore, these relationships influence the way in which individuals communicate (both verbal and nonverbal) with others. For instance, adolescents who are part of a support network do not display negative behaviors.  Adults will be less likely to be critical, reject their beliefs, or act out due to the fact that the adolescent receives affirmation of their opinions.

Protestants also took the initiative in advocating for religious freedom. Religious freedom was enshrined in England's new version of the "Bill of Rights" (1688), which asserted that "the pretended power of suspending the laws or the execution of the laws by regal authority without consent of Parliament is illegal" and that "erecting a multitude of new courts, and new officers, and giving them jurisdiction / to hear and determine causes, without the consent of the Commons is against law." Thus, religious freedom as separation of church and state was an early and important legacy of the English Reformation.

Before the early 20th century, treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore. Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of wounds, abscesses, and tumors included tar, tobacco juice, beer, wine, and urine. Many antibiotics were derived from these substances, however, it was not until the first antibiotic penicillin was found to be effective against infections in patients in the early 1940s that antibiotics started to be more widely used in treating patients. With the development of penicillin and numerous related antibiotics during that period, a variety of treatment options in modern medicine existed. Infections that were previously untreatable by modern medicine could now be successfully treated. Antibiotics had revolutionized medicine by providing physicians with the ability to combat a broad range of infections.

A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each, known as halves. Each half runs continuously, meaning that the clock is not stopped at half-time (which would give the team who was winning a "free-kick" to use the ball in an attempt to score more goals in a period of play).

Each team has a maximum of 10 players on each team. These players do not change during the playing of a match (although a goal scored by the second goalkeeper or penalty taker is allowed). No substitute or additional players may take the field for a team. The maximum number of substitutions is twice as many as the number of substitutions made in the first half of said match.

In addition to the maximum number of 10 players, teams may have an unlimited number of reserve players.

In 1681, in partial repayment of a debt, Charles II of England granted William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony. Despite his status as an indentured servant to the king, Penn was the only person named in the granting document—no attorney general, no notary, no governor or council, only Penn as "absolute proprietor" of all land in the colony. The colony was set up as a land-use democracy where land was apportioned by lot, and all property was exempt from taxation. It was open to "freemen"—that is, any white man who could read or understand English—with an exception for slaves. The land would be under the control of the proprietor for twenty-one years, renewable if he continued in office for longer.
