The classification of plants differs markedly from that of animals. The first thing that strikes the naturalist is the great difference between one plant and another. Each plant grows up into a highly characteristic form; each form is so different from some other plant that its existence is an important break in the system of nature. There are, indeed, exceptions, but generally the differences between one plant and another are greater than are those between one animal species and another. The vegetable kingdom is, accordingly, naturally divided into families, genera, and species, as in the animal

Hiberni (Ireland), Pictish (northern Britain) and Britons (southern Britain) tribes, all speaking Insular Celtic languages, appear not to have shared a unified sense of place. They all occupied territories in a wide zone around the island. This was a place in which peoples of distinct language, culture and ethnicity had lived side by side for an uncertain period over many centuries.

Britain was not a land divided into mutually exclusive zones of habitation. Instead, people had lived in several distinct zones, each with their own local names, over many centuries, but with a much greater degree of intermingling and interaction than in the more rigidly organized societies of mainland Europe. Sleep does not affect acquisition or recall while one is awake. Therefore, sleep has the greatest effect on memory consolidation. During sleep, the neural connections in the brain are strengthened, and more effective.

When a person thinks about a memory while awake, the memory is called a working memory. This is when the person uses the memory while going about normal activities. It is also when one makes connections in the brain.

When recalling a memory while asleep, it is called a non-working memory. This is because it does not require one to actively think about it while going about normal daily activities of the person. It is also when memories are more easily remembered.

While people of different ages, gender, or race may all have memory issues, it is important to remember that they are all created. Therefore, it does not matter which type a memory is, because they all have the same power and importance.

He writes that he "will not be satisfied until it is acknowledged by serious Islamicists and 'Western' scholars alike that the madrasa (however one defines it), particularly that of the ninth/tenth/eleventh/twelfth/etc. centuries, was an Islamic prototype and an integral component of the European university".

Criticism
Some writers have dismissed Makdisi's work and its influence on the literature as being primarily focused on demonstrating that the university, and not just the cathedral, is part of Islamic history. Writing in The Chronicle of Higher Education, Mark C. Carnes says that the primary argument is that the modern university is "indeed" an Islamic invention, "though we will never admit it."

Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding" plumage.

Breeding 

During the breeding season, the male bird of a pair begins by singing to attract females to their territory and also to provide a warning to other predators. Then, the pair engage in what is known as'song-exchange behaviour'.

The male bird will sing his own song, and at the same time his partner will imitate it from the branch to which her nest is attached. As the female's song becomes more sophisticated than the male's, the male takes a further step and changes into a new phase of song. This is called the "alternating song phase" and is usually achieved within a period of 24 hours, although the duration varies among different species. Song exchange is not confined to the territorial phase of the pair; it is sometimes repeated in subsequent seasons.

Viking invasions began in the 9th century, followed by more permanent settlements, particularly along the east coast of Ireland, the west coast of modern Scotland, and in the Outer Hebrides. They were largely unopposed, as the Irish in these areas were weakened by the fighting at home, and there were few well-established kingdoms in England to rally to their defense.

Many of these were small independent kingdoms, with small areas of dominance; some of the earliest kings of these peoples were de facto Kings of Wessex, in the South-West.

Viking activity in the British Isles was characterised by raids on coastal settlements and monasteries, and by plunder, enslavement and destruction of towns, villages and religious centres. As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of these detrimental radicals are blocked by scavengers. Oxidative stress, a state where the balance between radical damage and radical scavengers is upset, can lead to chronic health problems, such as the vascular and inflammatory diseases (cardiovascular disease, metabolic syndrome, osteoporosis, Alzheimer's, stroke, and obesity).

In 1905, Lord Curzon split the large province of Bengal into a largely Hindu western half and "Eastern Bengal and Assam", a largely Muslim-majority region which included then-independent Bengal Province.

The division, known as the partition of Bengal, has been controversial in the subcontinent ever since. This remains especially true in Bangladesh, where the effects of British imperialism continue to be highly emotive.

The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC. During the Spring and Autumn period, the Zhou vassal states developed their own distinctive styles of bronzeware making, often influenced by their own native styles. The Jin state was a center of bronze production, and the Wu, Chu dynasties were involved in bronze production.

Predators are often another organism's prey, and likewise prey are often predators. Though blue jays prey on insects, they may in turn be preyed upon by crows or hawks. An animal that feeds on another organism is called a parasite. An organism that feeds both on other organisms and on a non-living resource is a predator-prey.

The predator–prey relationship is often used in biology as a model for the relationship among organisms in a community. In a community, members of one group might be predators, members of another group might be prey; or groups might be at a competitive relationship, or at a cooperative relationship, or at some other relationship. For example, spiders and spiders-eating beetles are both predators of each other, yet are also in a competitive relationship.

As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century. But, by the 660s, the situation changed. In the West, the Lombards invaded Italy. In the East, the Sassanid Empire invaded Armenia. The Eastern and Western Empires were now vulnerable to an alliance of both. Despite their earlier differences, the Muslim and Byzantine Empires found common cause in their religious antagonism to the Arabs and their need of Christian support against a common foe. In 669, the Muslim ruler of Syria, Muawiyah, sent an ambassador to Constantinople suggesting they combine and launch an attack on the remaining Christian territories. The Byzantine emperor, Constans II, rejected the request outright but was persuaded to send envoys to Muawiyah. The result was the formation of a Muslim–Byzantine alliance.

By August 1805, Napoleon had realized that the strategic situation had changed fundamentally. Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies, he decided to strike back against Britain in the hope that one swift victory would achieve several objectives. To that end, a large armada of 74 ships of the line, supported by 1,200 transports, left Toulon by September 1805. These formed the biggest fleet yet deployed to the Mediterranean. Although its exact makeup remains controversial, its overall balance has been demonstrated to be sound by the modern historian Alfred Thomas.

The French were under the illusion that this was the same British fleet of 1794. However, no fewer than 14,000 reinforcements had been sent to the American theatre of war, weakening the British Mediterranean Squadron of the previous war, which was now represented mainly by three ships of the line and 10 frigates. As soon as pub customers began enjoying the taste of fresh beer, it became important to make the customers as efficient as possible and it became standard practice to have a tap located at the counter so that the beer could be poured directly into the mugs and tankards of the customers seated at the counter.

At a slightly later date, bars began serving liquor, and the customers were provided with free bar mugs. These mugs were supplied for a single glass and held around 125ml.

At the beginning of the 18th century, a more efficient form of the mug began to appear known as the JAR or JUG, and they were supplied with two pints.

The independence of the Thirteen Colonies in North America in 1783 after the American War of Independence caused Britain to lose some of its oldest and most prestigious colonies, including Canada. This led to the loss of revenues and the inability to pay her colonial wars against Spain and Napoleon. The wars, called the Revolutionary Wars in the United States were devastating for Britain, especially the naval war against the United States, which was costly in men, resources and ships. When Napoleon defeated the Russians at the Battle of Friedland on 14 June 1807, Britain was finally free of any continental threat and no longer needed Canada because of its large cost and poor natural resources. In 1807, Napoleon signed the treaty of Tilsit with Russia, essentially ending the threat of Continental warfare for Britain. By 1810, however, the Treaty of Amiens was not renewed, and Napoleon again prepared for a continental invasion. On 29 November 1947, the United Nations General Assembly recommended the adoption and implementation of the Partition Plan for Mandatory Palestine. This UN plan specified borders for a Jewish state (from the Jordan River to the Mediterranean Sea) and a Palestinian state (from the Mediterranean Sea to the Jordan River) and recommended that Jerusalem be internationalized. The partition plan was rejected by the Palestinian leadership, which argued that the whole of the British Mandate of Palestine should be partitioned and proposed an alternative UN plan, which proposed two states in the partition, for the whole of Palestine. However, a majority was unable to agree upon the creation of a Jewish state. On 15 May 1948 the Jewish forces of the Haganah attacked the Palestinian village of DeirYassin, massacred hundreds of residents, including women and children, and expelled and/or imprisoned the rest to the surrounding area. Valencia is a bilingual city: Valencian and Spanish are the two official languages. Spanish is official in all of Spain, whereas Valencian is official in the Valencian Community (a cultural region roughly coextensive with the historical Kingdom of Valencia). Valencian is a variety of Catalan, which is official in the neighbouring Catalonia region, whereas Spanish is the official national language of the rest of the country.

Valencia has the third-largest GDP in Spain, after Madrid and Barcelona. It is located on the delta of the Ebro River, and the Llobregat River, the rivers that contribute to this. Valencia is the largest and one of the most important industrial centers in the country.

While the idea is technically feasible, it raises a whole host of questions about the role internet service providers (ISPs) should play in the online environment.

So who wants your surfing data?

The idea is based on the fact that most browsers (Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, and Microsoft Internet Explorer in particular) keep logs of websites or "visited pages" you have visited, which is the data that Pai envisions.

How are ISPs going to know this information?

The islands are at relatively low altitudes, with central Ireland and southern Great Britain particularly low lying: the lowest point in the islands is Holme, at 10 metres (33 feet) above sea level, which lies in central County Durham.  Great Britain, as a mainland, is more elevated than Ireland, with central England ranging between about 130 and 170 metres (427–558 feet) above sea level.

Democratic Party candidates were consistently elected to local office, increasing the city's ties to the South and its dominant party. In 1861, Mayor Fernando Wood received 100% of the vote over Republican Gustav Bevan. As the American Civil War began, New York City remained a loyal stronghold of the Union.

Many of the non-alphanumeric characters were positioned to correspond to their shifted position on typewriters; an important subtlety is that these were not simply dropped at the left margin, but were moved over.  For example, the double prime mark used in British English (″) was shifted one position to the right; an uppercase L with top part cut off (ⓚ) was moved over from the bottom of the type to correspond to the double prime; superscripted ´ and ` were moved to occupy the space where a capital Q would be found on a typewriter; the long s was moved to the right one space, where it corresponded to an overstruck n; superscripted c and q were moved down one to the same position that an apostrophe would be; the circumflex was placed over the top part of the lowercase q; the uppercase a with dot top (Ą) was pushed down by the width of a period

Different phases of digestion take place including: the cephalic phase, gastric phase, and intestinal phase. The cephalic phase occurs at the sight, thought or smell of food. It is triggered off by receptors in the taste buds, olfactory cells, and throat. It produces the emotional feeling of acceptance. Gastric phase begins with the actual ingestion of food. It takes place in the stomach and produces feelings associated with hunger. Lastly, the intestinal phase takes places in the intestine where absorption begins. It is the main phase and produces the most feeling associated with the actual eating of any food.

Emotional eating is also closely linked to social interaction. Some people eat to relieve anxiety caused by lack of social interaction or to reduce feelings of loneliness. Another reason is to relieve the feelings of guilt arising from a transgression or to provide consolation for an offence. Often people eat to enhance mood or to provide comfort. Eating is a social behaviour which has been well received as a way of sharing emotions.

Species are increasingly being moved by humans (on purpose and not) for agriculture production, recreational, and other purposes without proper planning and regulation \[[@B1]-[@B3]\]. In the spring of 1800, Napoleon and his troops crossed the Swiss Alps into Italy, aiming to surprise the Austrian armies that had reoccupied the peninsula after the French Revolution. In the ensuing Battle of Marengo (or, as the victor called it, Buonaparte), French cavalrymen routed the Austrian cavalry in the first real defeat of the Austrians since the late 1700s. But in his pursuit after the battle, the French emperor neglected to hold off the Prussian-Austrian army, leaving a hole between those two armies that enabled Austrian forces to retake Milan and Venice.

It's often said that Napoleon's disastrous battle at Leipzig (16-19 October 1813), which inflicted nearly a quarter of a million casualties on the French army, had been caused by his failure to attack the Prussians immediately after Marengo: Leipzig, so the argument goes, would never have happened if Napoleon had immediately followed up his stunning initial victory. The first significant work that expressed scientific theory and knowledge expressly for the laity, in the vernacular, and with the entertainment of readers in mind came from a very unlikely place in the English context. The _Everyman_ Bible was a translation from two German texts, one produced by the Dominican Thomas à Kempis and another produced by the priest and professor of theology at the University of Wittenberg, John Wycliffe. These two projects grew out of a European humanist movement of writing literature in the vernacular that was intended to reach a wide audience (in Latin) in order to convey the "wisdom of the humanists" (Rome's own humanists) to people in a culture that was far removed from the cultural heart of Europe in Italy. At the heart of its purpose were the ideas of the reformation first articulated by Luther who had rejected the scholastic approach of studying religious texts in the Roman Catholic Church. Some street trams (streetcars) used conduit third-rail current collection. The third rail was below street level. The tram picked up the current, using the "leads" (the section of conductor and return rail between the rails). Other tram systems used trolley wire, overhead wire or a combination of the two.

London
Although an all-metal trolley railway had been tried on an experimental basis in the first half of the nineteenth century, it was not until the London and North Western Railway electrified several of its tramway systems in England between 1880 and 1885, that the modern tram car was born.  The electric tram, which was an instant success, paved the way for the rapid spread of electric railways, street trams, and trolley buses throughout the world, especially in the second half of the twentieth century.

In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the similarity in name, the phonograph was a fundamentally different invention because it used metal, not wood. It was first commercially recorded in 1889, and in 1890 it was the primary means for recording and transmitting human voice for the first time.

The invention of the phonograph opened up vast new areas of human expression that were only previously available musically or orally. Suddenly the masses could experience an orator or musician, or hear what a newscast sounded like, or get a first-hand recording of a politician's most important pronouncement.

The first commercially published musical recording was made in Berlin in 1857 by John Hill Hewitt, who recorded an oboe solo from Mozart's opera Don Giovanni. The first operatic or dramatic vocal recording was by Thomas Edison, who recorded an excerpt of the American soprano Lillian Nordica

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and maintenance. In ecology, it describes how organisms use energy and interact with their environments to survive in that environment. These interactions include eating other organisms, being eaten by other organisms, and having other organisms act on their own environment.

Biomass

In biology, and also in zoology, botany and other fields, biomass or biotic mass refers to the weight of living organisms. Biomass is useful for quantifying the rate of growth of living organisms. For example, the growth of food crops such as wheat or corn can be monitored by measuring the total weight of the crop. Or the growth of wildlife can be measured as the biomass of certain species.

In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism, Zoroastrianism, Mazdaism and Buddhism to Islam.

During the reign of Zayn al-Abidin (748–780 AD), one of these Arab converts, Ja'far al-Sadiq, who was a descendant of Amir Hamzah, became the fifth Imam of Twelver Shi'a and served as the political as well as religious leader of the entire Shi'a community. He was said to have been a descendant of Muhammad through his paternal line, but the actual relation is debated, some suggesting a direct lineage. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by large narrative cycles in which the history of the Christian world was interpreted in terms of the conflict between good and evil.

During his abdication Charles the Bald was at the height of his power. Over the next two hundred years the monarchy was split between rivals, and Carolingian art disappeared as public resources were diverted for private use. The earliest extant object in the new style is a silver chalice and processional cross in the shape of a bishop's staff, found at Himmelpforten, in the Harz mountains of southern Germany. Its style is marked by the presence of both figurative drawing and interlacing in the design. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid, a masterly reworking of Greek legends of the Trojan War and the wanderings of the Greek hero Aeneas after the fall of Troy, were destined to become for sixteenth-century Italians the most popular works of classical culture, the foundation of Renaissance culture. In Italy, too, the poems continued to be read. But Virgil's authority in Rome was so great that one of the great cultural traditions of the early modern world took its point of departure not in Milan or Mantua but in the shadow of the great city of Rome and in the writings that celebrated its founding.

By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury flights. The Americans were sure that their manned spacecraft would be more advanced and safer than the Soviets’ and predicted that they would be in space by 1964. The Soviet space program turned out to be considerably more advanced than expected by the Americans, and their Vostok I crewed spaceflight occurred in April 1961, four months before Gagarin’s flight.

The Space Race of the 1950s and 1960s was a watershed in American history, one that is far from over. If you want to learn more about the first years of the Space Age, consider reading a new title available soon from American Experience: First Step to the Moon, which is the third installment of a four-part series that documents this turbulent period in American history.

The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (primarily of a series of extinct volcanoes); the island rises from the ocean floor with a basalt core and is surrounded by hills, of up to 1,000 m (3,281 ft) in height. The island comprises five major landforms (or physiography provinces):

1. The mountains, which consist of two main ranges. The northern and western mountains, rising to over 3,000 m (9,900 ft), are a dissected range of volcanoes dating from 7000 to 500 BC; the eastern range consists of volcanic plugs. The largest of the mountains is Mont Buxton, at 3,060 m (10,005 ft), and the most remote, at 2,350 m (7,700 ft), is Mount Long.

The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia, and indeed has resulted in great domestic animal breeds which form part of our heritage, such as the ancient breeds of dog, pig and horse, and the modern breeds of cattle, sheep, goats and poultry. It has created many of the most important domestic animal breeds, and played a role in the increase from around 250 native European animal species in 3000 BC to some 600 in 1000 BC to close to 900 by the year 2000 (Preece _et al_. 2007). In particular, the role of hybridisation in the creation of the modern domesticated horse has been well documented, and the results have been impressive. A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, regarded God as an impersonal force. God was not conceived as possessing human qualities such as love, nor was he seen as concerned with humanity’s day-to-day problems. God was understood, instead, as a distant and unapproachable deity who had set the universe in motion (or, in other formulations, set the first rock into motion). And atheism, according to Voltaire, was the conclusion that no-one had ever proved (or even believed) the existence of God, or that his existence was essential for the establishment of morality. Atheism is often dated to David Hume’s 1754 work, An Inquiry Concerning Human Understanding. However, as Paine noted, atheism had been common before 1700, he just wished it to be discussed rationally and with modesty and decency

The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s.  The school became an American icon during the 1920s because of its winning football teams and Gaelic football teams in both Ireland and the United States.

Irish American support
At this time, about 60% of Notre Dame's student body was of Irish ancestry. Its Gaelic football teams were regarded as among the best in the world. In the 1916 football season, the Notre Dame football team achieved an 11–0 victory over Army, winning the national championship. Notre Dame's most successful football coach during the era was Knute Rockne, who won six national championships and two Olympic Gold Medals.

The Notre Dame vs. Army rivalry was one of the greatest in college football.  Army was a military college, and, although founded as an all-male college, allowed women to attend beginning in the 1920

Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: west and east of the main chain of the Alps, with valleys and plateaus, the central core of the Alps, where the mountainous peaks reach elevations of over 4,000 meters and glaciers are found at lower elevations, and the southern Alpine slopes, the glaciers and valleys of which are separated from the northern ones by the upper Engadin valley, which is occupied by the Inn river and a series of lakes. The three major river systems are the Rhône, the Rhine and the Engadine, which flow south to north; with its length of 1,650 km. Switzerland covers an area of 41,285 km^[@CR2]^. It has been an independent customs region since 1819, which has given rise to the formation of the federal state, which is based upon the original Swiss constitution

Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm as the boundary between the coldest and warmest months avoids the maritime moderation of average temperatures in the more maritime portions of New England. Also of note is the use of the 0 °C (32 °F) coldest degree day definition for determining the northern limit of the warm season. For areas with warm summers, the standard isotherm is a more realistic boundary between seasons in terms of temperature perception by the human eye. Also of note is that due to maritime influence in certain areas as well as the extreme difference between mean July and January, a cold season definition using the January isotherm gives a more realistic picture of the cold season (see [Fig. 2](#fig-2){ref-type="fig"}).

Many insects possess very sensitive and, or specialized organs of perception. Some insects such as bees can perceive ultraviolet wavelengths, or detect polarized light, while the pea aphid detects low levels of gravity to avoid the fall to the ground and a high enough sensitivity to fly upside down in the same way a helicopter would in the presence of low altitude gravity. Insects also possess many highly sensitive mechanoreceptive structures such as cribellar, campaniform, and sarciniform sensilla. There are also proprioceptors and hygroreceptors like tarsal organ, sensilla styloconica, sensillum basiconicum, and a scrobicular plate. In addition, many insects have specialized olfactory organs that act as chemoreceptors to sense chemical stimuli. These organs include antennal sensilla, sensory pits, campaniform sensilla, and antennal tubercles. There are also three known mechanosensors in the antenna, the chordotonal organs, camp

Israel's Supreme Court is at the head of the court system in the State of Israel. It is the highest judicial instance. The Supreme Court sits in Jerusalem. The court's President is known as the President of the High Court of Justice. The President of the Supreme Court presides over High Court judges and also sits in Jerusalem. The Supreme Court justices, the President of the Court, and the Judges of the High Court of Justice are all appointed by the President of Israel for a term of 9 years.

The Supreme Court may be the "Constitutional Court" because it is the court which finally settles issues related to the constitution of the state. Nevertheless, the Supreme Court can interpret the constitution but not enact it. All acts of the State of Israel enacted after independence, including constitutional amendments, require two-third majority approval in the Knesset, as an expression of will of the people. The _Essay_ develops a position that predictions become known as "tabula rasa" (blank slate) epistemology; that is, Locke's theory of cognition and epistemology makes a sharp division (and thereby demarcates sharply) between the innate knowledge (information carried in the brain) as contrasted with the knowledge derived from experience via the senses, that is, _tabula_ or the slate of the mind on which all of our knowledge is written by our experience.

Early Modern universities mantra continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages: natural philosophy, logic, medicine, theology, mathematics, astronomy (and astrology), music, and some practical aspects of agriculture. In response to the early-to-mid-17th 60s "continental rationalism" John Locke (1632–1704) proposed in 1689 his _Essay Concerning Human Understanding_. The work is a orthodox and empirical treatise on man and cognition. A powerful in epistemology and philosophy of mind and a chief representative of empiricist philosophy, Locke is celebrated particularly for his theory of language, which is built upon the thesis that human knowledge is the result of empirical experience and the senses. The _Essay_ develops a position that would become known as "tabula rasa" (blank slate) epistemology; that is, Locke's theory of cognition and epistemology makes a sharp enforcement (and thereby demarcates sharply) between the innate knowledge (information carried in the brain) as contrasted with the knowledge derived from experience via the senses, that is, _tabula_ or the slate of the mind on which all of our knowledge is written by our experience.

In the frenzied Battle of Marengo (or, as the victor called it, Buonaparte), French cavalrymen routed the Austrian cavalry in the first real defeat of the Austrians since the late 1700s. But in his pursuit after the battle, the French emperor neglected to hold off the Prussian-Austrian army, leaving a hole between those two armies that enabled Austrian forces to retake Milan and Venice. It's often said that Napoleon's disastrous battle at Leipzig (16-19 October 1813), which inflicted nearly a quarter of a million casualties on the French army, had been caused by his failure to attack the Prussians immediately after Marengo: Leipzig, so the argument goes, realised never have happened if Napoleon had immediately followed up his stunning memorial victory.

The deeper ancestral demography of Bermuda's population has been burtynsky's by the ethnic homogenisation of the last four centuries. There is effectively no ethnic heterogeneity now, but in the past all but ~1% of the population were of a single ethnic group (sub-Saharan African), which was replaced by a colonising group from a different continent. These were not the rules of conventional classical physics—no laws, formulas, or equations—for there was nothing but a single "all-inclusive law" for nature, known as the "Uncertainty Principle." It meant that the more precisely a particle could be predicted to be at any particular point in spacetime at a certain moment, the less the knowledge one had about the position and speed of every other particle in the universe. Because it was fundamentally impossible to measure and predict more precisely than this, the Uncertainty Principle implied that it was always more probable that two particles exist in this or that region of space at such-and-such a time interval than a particle is at another location right that very moment.
